Description: Cow horn flask covered with hide with attached carrying strap. The hide stretched around the horn and is stitched centrally along its length. A separate section of hide is stitched around the base of the horn and a carrying strap is threaded through the hide at the top and bottom, ending in an elaborate coiled knot. There is an piece of twisted copper wire around the tip of the horn.
Condition: Good; some cracks in leather covering.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 2nd Earl of Belmore
Acquisition notes: 1843,0507.291 to 1039 is a collection of antiquities from Egypt and neighbouring countries purchased from the Earl of Belmore, who had collected them when he travelled up the Nile as far as the second cataract in 1816-18. Within it there were 21 modern pieces, most of which are now considered to be from Ethiopia.
